content.content_body: Boston's @gardnermuseum enlisted the help of Prelle, the centuries-old French weavers, to bring an air of authenticity to the Raphael Room at the museum. This red fabric from the same time period as the paintings makes guests feel like royalty.

content.content_body:
#ElJaleo - #JohnSingerSargent 
After the initial exhibition of El Jaleo in 1882 at the French Salon, John Singer Sargent became, as one writer put it, "the most talked-about painter in Paris." ...In 1888 the painting was publicly exhibited in Boston, at which time museum patron #IsabellaStewartGardner, the heiress wife of a Coolidge cousin, expressed her interest in it. In 1914 she borrowed El Jaleo to exhibit in her museum, and constructed the Spanish Cloister gallery especially for El Jaleo, ...Coolidge then gave the painting to Gardner, and Sargent presented her with an album of pencil drawings he had made as preparatory sketches for the work. - fav from the Isabela w my fav homie.

 #prisma #prismacolor #prismaart #artofliving

content.content_body:
Produced by @gardenermuseum this year's Frank Hatch Free Day coincides with the last day of our special Exhibition Listen Hear: the Art of Sound. Our theme for the afternoon is Sounds of Blue, co-produced with local culture maker Adebukola Ajao of @bdyconsult. Featuring fashion showcase by Boston celebrity designer @josefa_da_silva coordinated by Provida Fashions and workshops by Project Runway designer @nathaliajmag in Calderwood Hall, Hostetter Gallery, the historic Palace and the Jordan Garden. Try your hand at natural dying techniques in the Bertucci Education Studio, and enjoy Latin jazz by the Edmar Colón Trio in the Courtyard.

content.content_body:
One of our favorite places in Boston! Add this to your travel list the next time you visit! 🙌🏻
 #Repost from @gardnermuseum - The art of landscape has been central to the Gardner Museum since its inception. Isabella Stewart Gardner constructed the Courtyard of her museum at precisely the moment when landscape architecture was first articulated as an academic discipline, liberal profession, and civic art. To this day, the Museum remains a preeminent cultural venue for landscape.
.
.

content.content_body: Another from @risdmuseum - Ogling a saucy dancer is not the way I generally imagine the great American painter John Singer Sargent! By the time this drawing was made, Sargent was a celebrity in his own right, and worthy of being captured by another artist in a moment of...inspiration? Sargent - the smiling bearded gentleman to the right - will in fact paint a portrait of the charming Carmencita, here giving a private performance for the wealthy friends of Bostonian art collector Isabella Stewart Gardener. I especially like the woman on the left, watching the performance with her lorgnette. "John Singer Sargent Watching Carmencita Dance at Mrs. Gardner’s Home in Boston" by Harper Pennington, 1890 #risdmuseum #harperpennington #johnsingersargent #americanart #americanartist #1890s #isabellastewartgardner #drawing #carmecita #dancer #dance #art #arthistory #historyofart #artlovers #heartart

content.content_body: The human boy is currently in Boston and he saw this interesting audio installation by Su-Mei Tse in collaboration with Jean-Lou Majerus entitled Sound for Insomniacs, 2007. For Tse, photographs alone are not enough to capture a cat's unique personality. Here, she presents large close-up portraits of five different cats, each with expressive presence similar to traditional painted portraits, along with recordings of each cat purring. The artist invites viewers to take a seat and listen with a headphone of each cat's purring sound while gazing into their individual portrait, suggesting that insomnia sufferers may fall asleep to the sound of the soothing purrs. #isabellastewartgardnermuseum #listenhere #theartofsound #sumeitse #soundforinsomniacs #catpurr #soundinstallation #audioart #catportraits #catlover #soundofcats #catpersonality #visitBoston #bostonmuseum #museumhopping #comebackhuman #artdiary #traveldiary #frankygoestoBoston #catstagram #catsdaily #artwork #isabellastewartgardner #catlovers #catlady #cat_of_instagram #travellingcats #artgram

content.content_body: This drawing is by famed French artist Edgar Degas. Degas is most well known for his depictions of ballerinas, many of whom he observed at the Opera Garnier in Paris. He was fascinated by dance as an artform, as was Gardner. Isabella purchased this piece with the help of American artist Louis Kronberg (who was also fond of painting ballerinas—several of his dancer tableaux hang in the Gardner galleries), for $500 on March 20, 1920. 🖼: Edgar Degas, A Ballerina (Danseuse à la barre), about 1880, Black and ochre chalk and pink and white pastel on paper

content.content_body: From cacti to air plants, everything seems to be in bloom at the Gardner Museum! Many people don’t know that cacti are flowering plants and that every variety of cactus is capable of blooming when it reaches maturity. Whether or not an individual cactus plant blooms depends on its age and the care it gets. Some cacti don’t bloom until they are more than 30 years old! Our horticulturists at the Gardner take care to ensure our cacti receive proper light, watering, and fertilization so they can reach their full blooming potential. 🌵🌸

content.content_body:
This painting by Frenchman Paul César Helleu is of the interior of the Basilica of Saint Denis, just north of Paris. Helleu was born in Brittany, France to a family of artists: both his father and grandfather were artistic directors for Chanel Parfums. This work hangs in a nook of Isabella’s Chapel at the end of the long gallery, mimicking the twelve-foot section of brilliant French High Gothic stained glass set over the altar.

Image: Paul César Helleu, The Interior of the Abbey Church of Saint Denis, about 1891, oil on canvas.

content.content_body: Listen Hear: The Art of Sound ends September 5. Come see Su-Mei Tse’s “Sound For Insomniacs,” a sonically interactive portrayal of five cats with strikingly human expressions, as well as many other immersive sound installations. This is the last weekend #ListenHear will be at the Gardner, so don’t miss your chance! Learn more: gardnermuseum.org/Listen-hear

content.content_body:
The gems set on these two identical bazubands, or armlets, are a variation of the traditional Indian talisman, the navaratna. This Sanskrit term means “nine gems,” which represent the nine planets of Hindu astrology. However, these bazubands are set with eleven gems: coral, pearl, turquoise, a yellow stone, sapphire, diamond, ruby, emerald, a pink gem, moonstone, and garnet. The seller of the armlets claimed they were once owned by the “queen of Delhi,” and seized by British soldiers during the Mutiny of 1857. Although the provenance cannot be confirmed, the size of the gems suggest the armlets belonged to a person of high rank.

Objects: Pair of Armlets (Bazubands), 19th century, gold on lac core with precious and semi-precious stones.

Just marveling at the sheer beauty of the colorful, Venetian-style courtyard at the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum yesterday. I had such an amazing time viewing the gorgeous flowers 🌺 and sculptures, as well as learning about the history behind the eclectic pieces of art inside and Gardner's main inspirations/dreams for her magnificent museum. So glad to have enjoyed my pre-Birthday celebration with my girl @rosemarie_4444! Thanks for your wonderful company & lovely gifts 💕💕📸
 #boston #isabellastewartgardner #museum #endofsummerfun
